title-group.article-title: Quantitative renal [99mTc]DMSA imaging predicts urinary [99mTc]DMSA excretion in patients with chronic kidney disease

sec.title: Background
sec.p: 99mTc-labelled Dimercaptosuccinic acid ([99mTc]DMSA) is a radiopharmaceutical commonly used to evaluate renal perfusion, structure, and morphology. However, the renal handling of [99mTc]DMSA in humans remains unclear. Studies in humans with renal tubular dysfunction and animal experiments suggest that renal uptake of [99mTc]DMSA occurs by glomerular filtration and subsequent proximal tubule reabsorption. The main aim of this study was to examine renal handling of [99mTc]DMSA and the pathophysiological implications of [99mTc]DMSA-based imaging in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) compared to healthy controls (HC).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA was 1.5-fold higher and more variable in CKD patients compared to HC. While [99mTc]DMSA plasma clearance was only 1.1-fold higher in HC, the [99mTc]DMSA uptake in the kidneys was 2.6-fold higher in HC compared to CKD patients and correlated inversely with the 24-hour urine excretion of [99mTc]DMSA independent of GFR.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Kidney [99mTc]DMSA accumulation is consistent with tubular uptake following glomerular filtration. The relative DMSA uptake is lower in CKD patients, pointing to defective proximal tubular function in this patient group. Furthermore, the results suggest that [99mTc]DMSA uptake could serve as a marker for tubule-interstitial function.

custom-meta.meta-value: © Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Dimercaptosuccinic acid labelled with 99mTc ([99mTc]DMSA) is widely used for non-invasive evaluation of kidney function, providing important information on renal perfusion, structure, and morphology [1]. [99mTc]DMSA is primarily used in paediatric imaging for the detection of renal scarring and parenchymal lesions, complications common to conditions like pyelonephritis and vesicoureteral reflux [2, 3]. Several studies have also shown that adult patients suffering from a wide array of tubular disorders present with markedly reduced renal uptake of [99mTc]DMSA [4–6]. Additionally, reduced kidney [99mTc]DMSA uptake has been observed in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) [7].

Previous studies suggest that [99mTc]DMSA accumulation in the kidney is dependent on extraction of [99mTc]DMSA by tubular cells from the peritubular capillaries [8, 9]. Conversely, an experimental study demonstrated that [99mTc]DMSA binds to alpha-one-microglobulin (A1M) in plasma, is filtered in the glomeruli [10], and reabsorbed by proximal tubule cells, followed by degradation within the lysosomal compartment [10, 11]. Thus, the exact mechanism of renal [99mTc]DMSA accumulation in humans and the pharmacokinetic properties of [99mTc]DMSA in the kidney remain unresolved.

CKD is defined as a persistent abnormality in renal structure or function, e.g., structural damage, a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) < 60 mL/min/1.73 m2, or urine albumin-creatinine ratio (uACR) above 30 mg/g [12]. Alongside glomerular dysfunction, the disease often involves impairment of proximal tubule transport [13–15].

As renal [99mTc]DMSA uptake may be dependent on the degree of proximal tubule impairment, this could potentially affect the results of a [99mTc]DMSA scintigraphy. Previous studies indicate that a decrease in kidney [99mTc]DMSA uptake is associated with the CKD stage [7] and risk of progression [16], but whether this represents a change in GFR-independent renal handling of [99mTc]DMSA has not been established.

Based on the conclusions of Weyer et al. [10], the quantification of [99mTc]DMSA uptake in the kidney parenchyma and the inversely correlated urinary excretion could therefore serve as a proxy for proximal tubule function, specifically in CKD patients. In CKD, disease stage and progression are conventionally monitored via filtration capacity (GFR) and glomerular barrier integrity (proteinuria), and the assessment of tubular impairment using [99mTc]DMSA could therefore represent a novel way of evaluating CKD stage and the risk for progression.

Thus, this study aimed to investigate renal [99mTc]DMSA handling in CKD patients and HC and to examine whether [99mTc]DMSA renal scintigraphy predicts urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA and thereby the degree of proximal tubule dysfunction in CKD patients. To identify the physiological processing of [99mTc]DMSA, we measured renal uptake and urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA in parallel with GFR determined by [51Cr]EDTA plasma clearance.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: A single-centre, observational, cross-sectional study, including healthy volunteers and patients with CKD newly referred for evaluation at the Department of Renal Medicine, Aarhus University Hospital. Healthy volunteers were recruited by advertising in local newspapers.

sec.title: Inclusion of CKD patients and healthy controls
sec.p: All CKD patients were included and examined at the Departments of Renal Medicine and Nuclear Medicine and PET Centre, Aarhus University Hospital between 27 May 2013 and 27 September 2015. Inclusion criteria were: (1) age between 18 and 80 years, (2) newly referred to the renal outpatient clinic, and (3) eGFR ranging from 15 to 60 ml/min/1.73m2 for the last 3 months. Exclusion criteria were: (1) acute kidney failure (defined as a decline in eGFR > 50% over the last 3 months), (2) previous kidney transplantation, (3) polycystic kidney disease, glomerulonephritis or renal vasculitis, and (4) pre-existing cancer and/or a life expectancy less than 18 months.

Inclusion criteria for healthy controls were age between 18 and 80 years old, no known renal disease or other pre-existing medical conditions, and no use of prescription medicine. Ten healthy male and ten healthy female volunteers were recruited.

sec.title: Examinations
sec.p: All participants underwent the same examination program. On the morning of the first day, a cannula for tracer injection and blood sampling was inserted into the cubital vein. Participants were instructed to empty the bladder, and a spot urine sample was collected marking the beginning of the 24-hour urine collection. At time 0, a single dose of 100 MBq [99mTc]DMSA (Mallinckrodt DRN 4334) and 4 MBq [51Cr]EDTA (Amersham CJ.13P) were injected intravenously in a quantitative manner followed by flushing of the cannula with 20 ml of normal saline. Blood samples of 9 ml were drawn in potassium-EDTA coated tubes at baseline and 5, 10, 20, 30, 45, 60, 90, 120, 150, 180, 210, 240, 270, 300, and 1440 min after tracer injection. Additional samples for plasma-creatinine analysis were collected in lithium/heparin-coated tubes after the 24-hour urine collection period. On the first day, blood was kept at room temperature until after the last scan (5 h after tracer injection). Samples were then centrifuged, pipetted, and analysed as described below. Urine samples were collected from the 24-hour urine container 2, 5, and 24 h after injection of the radiopharmaceuticals.

Fifteen-minute gamma camera scintigrams were obtained 2- and 5-hours post-injection using a Philips Brightview dual-head gamma camera. Simultaneous anterior and posterior images were acquired in a 128 × 128 matrix. The sensitivity of the two detectors was adjusted to be within a 1% difference. Attenuation of gamma rays in the patient table was ignored. Before scanning, the participants were asked to empty their bladder into a urine collection container. After the initial scan of kidneys and bladder, the urine container was scanned for 5 min.

sec.title: Plasma
sec.p: Plasma (P)-creatinine was analysed using a standardized, automated enzyme-linked absorption-photometric method on a Cobas® 6000 C machine (Roche Diagnostics International Ltd., Switzerland). eGFR was calculated using the CKD-EPI formula [17].

sec.title: Urine
sec.p: All urine samples for creatinine analysis were collected in clean tubes, centrifuged, and analysed using an automated enzyme-linked absorption-photometric method on a Cobas® 6000 C machine (Roche Diagnostics International Ltd., Switzerland). 24-hour urine creatinine clearance (UCCl) was calculated as: UCCl = 24-hour urine volume x 24-hour urine creatinine concentration/P-creatinine concentration.

sec.title: Plasma
sec.p: The plasma [99mTc]DMSA and [51Cr]EDTA activity were counted in 3 mL plasma samples in a scintillation detector (Cobra II, Packard, USA) including plasma blanks and a standard dilution of tracer to a statistical accuracy of 1%. A correction was made for background, radioactive decay, and crosstalk between channels. [51Cr]EDTA activity was counted 3 days after [99mTc]DMSA activity.

The plasma clearance of [99mTc]DMSA and [51Cr]EDTA were estimated as: Clplasma = Q0/AUC, where Q0 is the injected amount of tracer, and AUC is the area under the plasma curve. AUC was estimated by fitting the curve to the sum of three exponential functions using the peeling-off technique. 24-hour plasma samples were included in all plasma clearance calculations.

sec.title: Urine
sec.p: The urinary [99mTc]DMSA-activity was determined in timed urine samples collected at 120, 300, and 1440 min. A 3 mL sample of urine was drawn from a urine-collection-container after voiding and counted in a scintillation detector (Cobra II, Packard, USA) along with a standard dilution of tracer to a statistical accuracy of 1%. A correction was made for background and radioactive decay. All samples were counted for [99mTc]DMSA after the last scan. The total urinary DMSA excretion was calculated as the activity of [99mTc]DMSA in the urine sample multiplied by the total voided volume at the relevant time point.

sec.title: Scintigrams
sec.p: The regions of interest included the kidneys and bladder. These were defined by visual evaluation of the scintigram (Fig. 1). The amount of tracer in each region was determined as counts per second (CPS) within the region. Background corrections were made by drawing representative background areas for each organ, and subtracting CPS after scaling for difference in area. To compensate for differences in depth, organ CPS were measured in both anterior and posterior images, and the geometric mean (square root of the product of anterior and posterior CPS) was used as a corrected measure for organ activity. All measurements were decay-corrected back to the time of injection. Images obtained at 2 h and 5 h were analysed by comparing the total CPS over the kidneys in percent of the total CPS over the kidneys, bladder, and urine container. Image analysis was performed using Image-J (version 2.0.0-rc-43/1.50e) software.

caption.p: A representative example of a scintigram of a CKD patient and the areas used for analysis.
Figure was generated using Stata BE17.0 (StataCorp)

sec.title: Calculations
sec.p: Accumulated kidney activity at 2 h (KU2) and 5 h (KU5) representing the uptake or retention in the kidneys were calculated in percent of the total 99mTc-DMSA retained in the entire urinary tract. Thus, KU2 and KU5 are believed to represent the fraction of filtered [99mTc]DMSA accumulated in the kidneys at these time points. To further examine renal handling of DMSA, we compared the urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA to the activity present in the renal and urinary tract scintigrams, both at 2 h and 5 h after administration of [99mTc]DMSA. A strong linear correlation was observed between the CPS in the urine collection and the percentage of Q0 in urine at 2 and 5 h, showing that scanning of the urine container is a valid measure for the excretion of the radiopharmaceutical (data not shown).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Data analysis and figures were made in Stata 17 (StataCorp). All data were tested for normality using visual inspection of QQ-plots comparing the experimental data to a theoretical normal distribution. Data were hereafter log transformed if needed.

Before any linear regression analysis, the distribution of data was visually evaluated to prevent bias by heteroscedasticity. All tests were two-tailed and performed at a significance level of 5%. Students’ t-test and regression analysis were used where applicable.

sec.title: Baseline characteristics
sec.p: 38 CKD patients and 20 HC were included in the study. They differed significantly with respect to age, BMI, eGFR, [51Cr]EDTA-plasma clearances (GFR), and comorbidities (Table 1).

caption.p: Clinical characteristics and results of radio-pharmaceutical analyses in CKD patients and HC. Numbers in brackets represent SD unless followed by a %

sec.title: The plasma clearance of [99mTc]DMSA correlated weakly with GFR and differed slightly between the groups
sec.p: The 24-hour plasma clearance of [99mTc]DMSA revealed a weak but significant, positive correlation with [51Cr]EDTA plasma clearance in both CKD patients (r2 = 0.45, p < 0.05, Fig. 2) and HC (r2 = 0.22, p < 0.05, Fig. 2). Additionally, [99mTc]DMSA plasma clearance was marginally higher in HC (Table 1).

caption.p: The correlation between [99mTc]DMSA and [51Cr]EDTA plasma clearances. A weak but statistically significant positive correlation was identified in both study groups. The linear regression fit is better in the CKD group.
Figure was generated using Stata BE17.0 (StataCorp)

sec.title: Urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA differed between CKD patients and HC but was independent of GFR
sec.p: The 24-hour urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA relative to the injected total dose of [99mTc]DMSA was 1.5-fold greater in CKD patients compared to HC (18.2% vs. 11.9%, p = 0.003). The 24-hour urinary [99mTc]DMSA excretion did not correlate significantly with mGFR, measured as plasma [51Cr]EDTA clearance, in either group (HC: p = 0.79, CKD: p = 0.82, Fig. 3).

caption.p: The proportion of injected [99mTc]DMSA excreted after 24 h and [51Cr]EDTA plasma clearance. No significant correlation is present, r2 is below 0.1 in all regressions.
Figure was generated using Stata BE17.0 (StataCorp)

sec.p: As expected, a strong, positive linear correlation was observed between the total CPS associated with the bladder and the urine container at 2 and 5 h and the fraction of injected [99mTc]DMSA excreted in the urine at 24 h, both in CKD patients (p < 0.001) and controls (p < 0.001).

sec.title: The [99 mTc]DMSA accumulation in the kidneys was independent of GFR and lower in CKD patients, correlating inversely with urinary [99 mTc]DMSA activity
sec.p: The [99mTc]DMSA accumulation in the kidneys at 2 and 5 h (KU2 and KU5) did not correlate significantly with mGFR in the CKD patients (p = 0.47) or the HC (p = 0.79) (Fig. 4). The relative kidney accumulation (kidney vs. urine + bladder + kidney accumulation) was significantly lower in CKD patients compared to HC both at 2 and 5 h (2 h: 0.63-fold lower, 43.7% vs. 68.9%, p < 0.001 and 5 h: 0.55-fold lower, 35,7% vs. 64.8%, p < 0.001). Furthermore, the kidney accumulation of [99mTc]DMSA at 2 h and 5 h correlated inversely with the 24-hour urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA in both CKD patients (p < 0.001) and HC (p < 0.001) (Fig. 5).

caption.p: The correlation between KU2 and KU5 and [51Cr]EDTA plasma clearance. No significant correlation is identified, r2 is below 0.1 in all regressions.
Figure was generated using Stata BE17.0 (StataCorp)

The correlation between excreted [99mTc]DMSA and KU-values in the 2 and 5-hour scans. A statistically significant, negative correlation is observed at 2 and 5 h. The slope of the HC group does not differ significantly from the slope of the CKD group at any time point. The fit of the linear regression is better in the 2-hour scan and generally better in the CKD group.
Figure was generated using Stata BE17.0 (StataCorp)

sec.title: Total [99 mTc]DMSA in the urinary tract and urine (kidney, bladder, and urine collection container) was lower in CKD patients compared to HC, primarily due to decreased accumulation in the kidney
sec.p: To evaluate whether differences in urinary [99mTc]DMSA excretion were associated with differences in the total [99mTc]DMSA in the kidney and urogenital system, we compared the distribution of [99mTc]DMSA in the urinary system relative to the percentage of total injected amount.

sec.title: Two hours
sec.p: The mean total urinary tract and voided CPS (the kidney, bladder, and urine container) was significantly lower in the CKD patients compared to HC (8.1% of Q0 vs. 12.3% of Q0, p < 0.001) representing a reduction in the urinary tract and urine activity of approximately 43% in the CKD patients. Notably, accumulation of [99mTc]DMSA in the kidney was 62% less in CKD patients compared to HC (3.2% of Q0 vs. 8.5% of Q0, p < 0.001), while the urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA relative to the injected tracer did not differ significantly between the two groups (4.9% of Q0 and 3.8% of Q0, p = 0.13). Thus, the difference in accumulated urinary tract [99mTc]DMSA is most likely due to a combination of reduced renal plasma clearance and subsequent reduced uptake in the proximal tubules.

sec.title: Five hours
sec.p: At 5 h, the mean total urinary tract and voided CPS (kidney, bladder, and urine container) did not differ between CKD patients and HC (14.8% of Q0 vs. 18.4% of Q0, p = 0.25).

Conversely, the renal accumulation of [99mTc]DMSA was 2.6-fold higher in the HC compared to the CKD patients (11.9% of Q0 vs. 4.6% of Q0, p < 0.001). Furthermore, the CKD group presented with 1.6-fold higher urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA (CPS over bladder and urine-container) compared to HC (10,2% of Q0 vs. 6.5% of Q0, p = 0.018). This is consistent with a reduced kidney uptake of filtered [99mTc]DMSA in the CKD patients.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study demonstrates that renal uptake of [99mTc]DMSA inversely correlates with the urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA and is independent of GFR. This suggests a GFR-independent renal accumulation of [99mTc]DMSA. We advocate that this is due to post-glomerular, tubular uptake of [99mTc]DMSA, possibly mediated via proximal tubule reabsorption.

As the renal DMSA accumulation was reduced in the CKD patients, this proposed mechanism of proximal tubular transport was impaired in the patient group. This is based on the following observations: (1) The absolute amount of [99mTc]DMSA accumulated in the kidneys was significantly lower in the CKD patients compared to the HC, (2) the urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA in the CKD patients was higher compared to the HC both 5 and 24 h after injection. Thus, the fraction of injected [99mTc]DMSA in the kidneys was significantly lower in the CKD patients compared to HC, despite comparable (at 2 h) or greater (5 and 24 h) urinary [99mTc]DMSA excretion in the CKD group. This suggests that the difference in renal uptake of [99mTc]DMSA was not due to differences in the glomerular filtration of the marker and corroborates the concept that renal [99mTc]DMSA accumulation reflects the combined effects of filtration and subsequent tubular uptake.

As far as we know, this GFR-independent urinary tract accumulation of [99mTc]DMSA has not been demonstrated before. A previous study examining the relative 24-hour renal [99mTc]DMSA uptake in 55 patients did show a correlation between GFR and [99mTc]DMSA uptake. However, when examining patients with GFR < 20 ml/min/1,73 m2, the correlation disappeared [7]. As mentioned, previous studies have demonstrated a reduced renal uptake of [99mTc]DMSA in patients suffering from a wide range of tubular disorders [18, 19]. Murine experiments suggest that the reabsorption mechanism can be attributed to α1-microglobulin-bound [99mTc]DMSA being filtered and reabsorbed in the proximal tubules by megalin/cubilin-mediated endocytosis of the [99mTc]DMSA protein complex [10]. Our findings are consistent with this hypothesis, suggesting that tubular dysfunction may affect the evaluation of [99mTc]DMSA-based renal imaging, especially in late-stage CKD patients.

Utilising DMSA-based imaging to evaluate proximal tubular absorptive function could potentially provide new non-invasive information concerning the contribution of the proximal tubular compartment to kidney disease progression.

Although our results, in accordance with experimental murine data [10], support a tubular uptake of [99mTc]DMSA largely independent of filtration (Fig. 3), it cannot be excluded that a critically low GFR may impair [99mTc]DMSA accumulation.

The plasma clearance of [99mTc]DMSA among HC in our study was much lower than previously reported by Lange et al. [20], showing a mean plasma clearance of 34 ml/min in comparable healthy controls. We estimated [99mTc]DMSA-clearance based on 24-hour plasma samples, and since filtered and reabsorbed [99mTc]DMSA is most likely degraded in the proximal tubular cells, the 99mTc label may recirculate to plasma, thus leading to an underestimation of the renal filtration of [99mTc]DMSA in the present study. This is supported by a study showing that 200 min after the injection of 14C labelled DMSA into rabbits or monkeys, no intact [99mTc]DMSA could be identified in the plasma in any of the animals [11]. However, DMSA fragments (C14 activity) were identified up to 72 h after tracer injection, consistent with the metabolism of labelled DMSA.

Another explanation for the discrepancy between the clearance found in this study and the one reported by Lange et al. is difference in sampling time. Whereas our clearance was based on 24-hour plasma samples, Lange et al. had a sampling time of 4 h following an equilibrium period of 1.5 h.

Furthermore, the interpretation of DMSA scans is complicated by extrarenal accumulation of the tracer and alterations in input function due to possible functional imbalances between the two kidneys of an individual.

Several pathophysiological conditions affect the biodistribution of DMSA, mainly leading to increased accumulation in the liver [21]. Acidosis has been shown to increase this extrarenal uptake of the tracer [22] and could therefore confound the scan interpretation in individuals suffering from this condition, e.g. late-stage CKD patients. However, patients and controls had comparable plasma-total CO2, suggesting that acidosis is less likely to have affected the results. While differences in function between the two kidneys were not explicitly examined in the study, the decrease in renal function of the patients included in this study is typically not caused by unilateral organ affection.

Thus, although functional imbalances between the two kidneys of an individual complicate the usage of absolute DMSA uptake as a marker of overall kidney function [23], and the impact of this on the current findings is not known, we believe it is unlikely to change the overall conclusions of the study.

Furthermore, the uptake measurement is also complicated by the semiquantitative method used for imaging, with only static images at two timepoints, and no corrections for variation in attenuation among patients.

The CKD patients had significantly greater BMI, and thus probably more tissue in the abdominal region. This might result in an underestimation of the total uptake in the CKD patients, and thus potentially contribute to the observed difference between the patients and controls.

All these factors hinder the usage of [99mTc]DMSA uptake as a marker for generalised kidney function and must be taken into careful consideration when evaluating [99mTc]DMSA uptake as a marker for proximal tubular function specifically.

To our knowledge, this study is the first to examine the renal uptake of [99mTc]DMSA in CKD patients compared to healthy controls. Although only 38 patients, the CKD population represented a wide spectrum of GFR, age, and co-morbidity. All experiments were performed systematically and uniformly at the same department and by the same investigator using standard methods, thus minimising any errors due to inter-individual and regional differences in handling of samples and methods, adding to the reproducibility and uniformity of our data.

The low number of study participants limits the possibility of evaluating disease and age-specific differences in [99mTc]DMSA handling. The healthy controls were not age-matched with the CKD group, and thus we cannot exclude an age-dependent effect on the differences in [99mTc]DMSA handling. However, some CKD patients had a relative [99mTc]DMSA amount comparable to individuals in the HC group, indicating it is not an age-related phenomenon. An additional limitation of the study is the lack of matching regarding comorbidities and medication between the CKD patients and controls. Several of the listed comorbidities and medications in the CKD group are known to affect kidney function and could potentially impact [99mTc]DMSA handling as well.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The relative kidney [99mTc]DMSA accumulation was inversely correlated with the urinary excretion of [99mTc]DMSA and independent of GFR. This supports a GFR-independent renal recovery of [99mTc]DMSA and is consistent with a proximal tubule-dependent uptake of [99mTc]DMSA. Hence, caution should be shown when evaluating [99mTc]DMSA scintigrams in patients with CKD, as differences in renal [99mTc]DMSA accumulation may not be attributed solely to renal blood flow and filtration capacity. Furthermore, [99mTc]DMSA scintigraphy could be utilised as a potential method for non-invasive evaluation of tubular protein reabsorption function.

These findings hold the potential to aid the decision process for clinicians when evaluating and differentiating kidney function in CKD patients and are therefore of significant value to the field of diagnostic nuclear medicine.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Lene Elsebeth Nielsen is gratefully acknowledged for her excellent technical assistance, as is the late Michael Rehling for his sharing of basic knowledge regarding kidney physiology and nuclear medicine.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: The original conceptualization and design of the study was carried out by DJ, HB and JF. DJ was overall responsible for the inclusion of patients and controls. The data included in this paper have not been published elsewhere. The CKD patients and controls are a part of a larger cohort named the PUMA cohort. The cohort consists of a total of 82 people with CKD stage 3–4. Baseline characteristics and prospective disease progression of the PUMA cohort have been published previously [24, 25].

DJ: conceptualisation, data analysis, writing of original draft, project administration. JFA: data analysis, review and editing, visualization, project administration. PB: data analysis, review and editing, visualization. HB: conceptualisation, data analysis, writing of original draft, review and editing, supervision, funding acquisition. CF: data analysis, resources. JF: conceptualisation, resources, supervision, funding acquisition.
All authors critically revised the manuscript and provided central comments and corrections for the final version.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This work was conducted with financial support from the Danish Kidney Association Research Foundation, The A.P. Moeller Foundation for the Advancement of Medical Science, Helen and Ejnar Bjoernow’s Foundation, Danish Society of Nephrology, and P. Carl Petersen’s foundation.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: All datasets generated and analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on request.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent
notes.p: The study was approved by the Regional Ethics Committee (Committee 1, case file 1-10-72-535-12) and conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Informed consent was obtained from all participants prior to inclusion.

notes.title: Conflict of interest
notes.p: HB reports speaker fees and/or serving on advisory boards for Novo Nordisk, AstraZeneca, Bayer, Boehringer Ingelheim, Galapagos, GlaxoSmithKline, Alexion, Otsuka Pharmaceuticals, MSD, and Vifor Pharma; received research grants from Novo Nordisk, GlaxoSmithKline and Vifor Pharma; and serves as chairman of the Danish Society of Nephrology and the Society’s working group on the Danish CKD guidelines outside the submitted work.
